content: This contribution hasn’t received enough positive votes from the community. The "REVERSE" option has therefore been deactivated.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Harder than normal in Reverse, yet still doable. Overall, good clash!

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: This is a relatively simple exercise for code golf, and would be extremely challenging in Reverse, but probably possible.
I feel the urge to add a test that Rickrolls the solver, just because. :)

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: A good clash.
It's going a be challeging for reverse mode :)

Good job, i like it !
Your suggesting solution isn't very short....
Here is what i have :
for i in' '*int(input()):s=input().replace(" ","").upper();print(max(ord(l)for l in s)-min(ord(l)for l in s))

I think validators must be more similar than test (but not identical), You have validators with a different number of sentences and very different sentences.

The idea behind this is nice, but I think the introduction sentence could be improved. I often see clashes of code where you cannot understand the introduction sentence because it contains words you can't just google. As said in a comment by Husoski lexographical distance isn't understandable for everyone and most of the coders here don't speak english natively.
Except that I think it is a nice idea and should be definitely added!

I'm not seeing a definition of "lexicographical distance" here.  Wikipedia doesn't have that as an article name or even useful section title, either.   I predict the mode score in a typical clash will be 0%.  

Try explaining that you want the greatest difference between the ASCII codes of any two *letters* in the sentence.  That's what your code is doing.   With that change, this this might be okay for a "fastest" clash (pretty easy, especially in languages with built-in max and min operations), but is a bit more interesting in "shortest" mode as a golf problem.  

You still have the same words in validators as you do in the corresponding tests.  That makes the validator answers the same as the open test cases, and makes the problem vulnerable to "hard coding".

When @snoyes said "similar to, but different than", he meant that the validator should probe the same edge/corner cases as the test, but with different values so the solver can't guess from the open Input/Output pairs what the hidden validator Input or Output values are.

<annoying-spelling-cop-mode>
And I think the word you're looking for in Test 3 is "leisure".  
</annoying-spelling-cop-mode>
Validators are to be similar to, but different than, test cases. This prevents simply hardcoding the answers.

In the statement, please rectify the word lower in "the highest ascii value of the lower letter".

In the input and output, please read the input description to make a better description of how the data is arranged.
Thank you for your support! I did some changes

Thank you for the support!
I changed the solution and add more relevant test vectors

Indeed! Actually I hesitate to put any printable ASCII character and the idea would be to compute not the difference in ascii value but the alphabetical distance between letters only. For instance A and b have a distance of 1 as a and b would have

@Husoski, You say "Try explaining that you want the greatest difference between the ASCII codes of any two *letters* in the sentence.  That's what your code is doing."

Is this what the code is doing?
From what I can tell, this code doesn't take the difference between any two letters, it takes max(ord(letters)) (highest ascii value of the letters in the sentence) and the (ord(letters)) (lowest ascii value of the letters in the sentence) and returns the difference between them - for each line in the input.

I think "the greatest difference" in the description makes this puzzle really misleading, so the word "greatest" should be removed.

Nice puzzle, though. Would make for a very challenging reverse.
